results.title: Painting by numbers (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A program about the history and development of computer graphics and the way that artists and industrialists are exploring the potential of this ‘new’ technique. Includes interviews with film director George Lucas about film-making applications, the engineer who invented the first video game and uses in training airline pilots. Narrated by Paul Vaughan. Music by Paddy Kingsland. Written by Alec Nisbett.

results.title: Mary Mackillop
results.creator_credit: Mark Callan, Film Australia, Pamela Vanneck and Ron Saunders
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Willesee’s Australians”.
Mary McKillop was working as a tutor in 1861 when she decided to dedicate herself to the education of the poor, and devote herself to God. She became Sister Mary of the Cross of the Order of St Joseph, which was Australia’s first religious Order. Unlike other Orders, it placed itself outside the control of the local Bishop, which caused great feelings of resentment. Mary McKillop’s story is an extraordinary example of the power of the human spirit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mark Callan, Film Australia, Pamela Vanneck and Ron Saunders

results.title: Swan Lake
results.creator_credit: John Phillips, Francis Coleman and Ceidrik Heward
results.brief_description: Tchaikovsky wrote “Swan Lake” as a commission from the Bolshoi Ballet Theatre in 1875. The full ballet was not produced however, until 1895, after the composer’s death. It captivated audiences then, as it has done ever since, becoming the best loved ballet. This production by the Royal Ballet is descended almost directly from the original St. Petersburg production, with the addition of choreography by Ninette de Valois, Rudolf Nureyev and Sir Frederick Ashton. Performed by Natalia Makarova and Anthony Dowell in the leading roles at The Royal Opera House Covent Garden. There is a brief introduction to the history of the ballet.

results.title: Well, what are you doing now?
results.brief_description: This is a unique video made by a group of older Australians which promotes positive images of older adults in a range of community recreation activities. The group have demonstrated their capacity to master technical audio visual equipment and produce a challenging VHS video.

results.title: The Hero of the Dardanelles
results.brief_description: Made as a patriotic recruiting film, endorsed and assisted by the Department of Defence. This is the story of the careers of two brothers, one who has already enlisted in the Army and another, William, who soon follows his example. The film shows Will being trained and while on his final leave, persuading his pal to enlist. His patriotism and enthusiasm for the war is simple and unquestioning, and he is the pride of his wealthy family and sweetheart. They hold a banquet in his honour and he is clearly established as an upperclass hero who will doubtless be good officer material in the Army. Once his boat leaves for Egypt, the progress of his story is unknown, for the remainder of the film is no longer in existence. Cast, Fred Francis, Guy Hastings, Loma Rossmore, C. Throoby, Ruth Wainwright.

results.title: A Nation is built
results.brief_description: Frank Hurley (1885-1962) was firmly established by 1925 as Australia’s most famous photographer. His nature portraits became a model for many local filmmakers who tried to emulate his high technical standards and good romantic manner. After filming in many exotic locations, such as Antarctica and Papua New Guinea, Hurley remained in Australia in the 1930’s to become the dominant figure in Australian documentary, making short industrial films for government and private sponsors, such as this film, “A Nation is Built”. Sponsored by the New South Wales government to mark 150 years of white Australian settlement.

results.title: His Royal Highness
results.creator_credit: F.W. Thring and Efftee Film Productions
results.brief_description: George Wallace plays a stage-hand who dreams that he is King. This is Efftee’s third feature and the first all Australian talking musical film. Some lively songs and an ingenious comic performance by George Wallace. Cast also includes Mona Barlee, Marshall Crosby, Lou Vernon.

results.title: The Australian Alps: Mirka's Palace of Dreams
results.creator_credit: David Greig, Bill Murphy, David Morgan and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
This program is the last in a series of 6 documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia.
Mirka Mora is an eccentric artist, French by birth, who had never before ventured into the wilderness nor slept in a tent. Along with Tim McCartney Snape, the first Australian ever to reach the summit of Mt. Everest, and a Nepalese Sherpa, she travels into the Kosciusko wilderness. Mirka’s unique and expressive personality helps viewers see and experience this wilderness from an artist’s perspective. A Teacher’s guide accompanies the video.

results.title: Roads to Xanadu. Part 1: Episodes 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, John Merson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Roads to Xanadu is an intriguing investigation of the dynamic inter- change between East and West in the making of the modern world. Episode 1: “The Price of Harmony” dramatically re-creates the atmosphere of 13th Century China, the richest and most powerful Empire of those times. Episode 2: “The Invention of Progress” examines the interplay and conflict between Europe and the East, which began with the arrival of the Jesuit missionaries in Asia in the 16th Century.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Roberts, John Merson and Film Australia
results.description: Roads to Xanadu is an intriguing investigation of the dynamic inter- change between East and West in the making of the modern world. Episode 1: “The Price of Harmony” dramatically re-creates the atmosphere of 13th Century China, the richest and most powerful Empire of those times. Episode 2: “The Invention of Progress” examines the interplay and conflict between Europe and the East, which began with the arrival of the Jesuit missionaries in Asia in the 16th Century.

results.title: Bitter Surrender
results.brief_description: A documentary about an overlooked aspect of adoption, the experience of mothers who have surrendered or given up their children. Through the personal accounts of five women, it explores and exposes what the legally enforced secrecy surrounding adoption hides, that the majority of women who relinquish their children face seemingly unresolvable shame and grief.
